div1.p: [Carter] discusses the prevention of yellow fever, including past experiments involving control of the human host vs. control of mosquitoes.

div1.head: Lecture on the Prophylaxis of Yellow Fever, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]
div1.p:
Yellow fever is contracted by man from the bite of a certain mos-
quito--itself infected by having fed on a man sick of that disease and
we know of no other way in which, in nature, it is contracted.

Here are two propositions--one a positive statement of knowledge:
that yellow fever is conveyed by a certain mechanism: The other a state-
ment, positive, indeed, but of limitation of knowledge rather than of
knowledge itself.

For the first there can be no question. The experiments
of Reed and his Coadjutors---------------at Quemados------------in 1900
of Guiteras & John Ross------------------at Havana-------------- " 1901
of Ribas---------------------------------at Sao Paolo----------- " 1901
of Parker: Beyer & Porthier--------------at Vera Cruz------------ " 1903
indeed, of all who have attempted to convey the infection in this way,
prove this. It is a positive proposition and admits of positive proof,
and that proof is definite and abundant.

For the 2nd. proposition, I am in somewhat of a quandary:--To make
the direct negative statement: “that yellow fever is conveyed in no other
way,” would imply that we have investigated all other ways and found
them negative. This we have not done and hence the postulate is in its
present form.

We have investigated a number of what were considered probable or
possible methods of conveyance--by experiment or by epidemiological
studies--and from the standpoint of the sanitarian, I believe we can--
for the Americas at least--make the direct negative statement: “and is in
nature contracted in no other way.”
Space.

Is this alternative life of the causative organism in man and the
mosquito a metaxeny? We have not the same knowledge of its life history
history
2
in its hosts as of the malaria parasite and it may be a question. I think
it is: Noguchi does not, yet is not absolutely clear about it.

There are three participants in the Conveyance we have predicated:
(1) The Man infective to the Mosquito.
(2) The Mosquito infective to Man.
(3) The Man infected by the Mosquito.

I must, to an extent, discuss them, but I can only give you such data
on each as is minimally necessary for you to understand the prophylaxis
of yellow fever.
Space.
1/ The Man Infective to the Mosquito.

He is not infective for long. It is generally stated that the man
sick of yellow fever is not infective to mosquitoes after the 3rd. day of
illness. This is not proven. What is true is that no mosquito has been
proved infective to man which had fed only on a man more than 3 days ill.
Not many tried--why?
3 to 4 cases---say 10-15 insects.

Stronger evidence than the above, also negative, is the following:
The Commission of the Pasteur Institute--working at Rio in 1903--injected
4 men with the blood of a man--the same man--sick 4 days of yellow fever:
None of them developed it therefrom. One was afterwards shown to be sus-
ceptible--the others were believed to be so. The injection of blood from
a patient in the first days of the attack had been shown--by Carroll and by
Guiteras--to be a very certain way of conveying yellow fever, and we might
admit that the blood of this man was not infective on the 4th. day, but
whether the experiment proves that the blood of all men is free from in-
fectivity on the 4th. day of the attack--judge you. This is all the evi-
dence we have.

We may say, I think, that the evidence justifies the statement that
the patient is only infective for the first few days of the attack, but
I would not consider the end of the 3rd. day as a proven limit.
limit.

Two attempts to infect Stegomyia from men in the stage of incuba-
tion have proven negative. Too few, I think, for any deduction. There
is epidemiological evidence--indeed proof--that a man can “infect his en-
vironment”--that is, the mosquitoes therein, in the first few hours of
his illness.

There is no evidence for the existence of “Carriers” of yellow fever
infection. There is considerable of the contrary.
2/ The Mosquito Infective to Man.

(1) The mosquito incriminated is Aedes (Steg.) aegyptus. (History
of names: 26 aliases: this one probably last--Linnaeus 1762).
Space.

I say “for the Americas at least.” Epidemiological data exclude, I
think, any other vector as possible in America, but there is in Africa:
S. E. Asia and even in Hawaii, a mosquito of the same sub-genus--Aedes
(Stegomyia) scutellaris (or alba picta) very like aegyptus in its character-
istics--a little less domestic, not yet as completely weaned from knot-
holes and axils of leaves to man-made artificial containers as our American
species. There is not a particle of evidence incriminating this insect as
a vector of yellow fever, and not a particle to the contrary. It is, how-
ever, so like our known vector that one cannot but feel doubtful about it.
Space.

(2) It is generally stated that not less than 12 days must elapse
from the infecting feeding before the insect becomes infective to man.
Again a positibe statement of a negative proposition. That is true is that
no mosquito has been proved to be infective to man, in experimental work, un-
til at least 12 days have elapsed since feeding on the patient.

Quite a fair number of mosquitoes have been tried, however, many more
than for the 3 day limit of time for the sick man. All with negative re-
sults.

There is also a considerable amount of epidemiological evidence on
on
4.
this matter and I think we can say with a reasonable degree of confidence,
that a considerable time--minimally about 12 days, if you like--elapses
from the date a mosquito becomes infected before it is capable of convey-
ing infection to man." It is on the existence of this interval--without
predicating its exact length--that I base my opinion on the metaxeny of
the causativeorganism in man and mosquito.

The existence of this interval was determined before that of the
conveyance of yellow fever. Indeed, its determination by epidemiological
studies led to the latter:--determined the direction of the Quemados ex-
periments.

(3) Once infective, the mosquito stays so indefinitely--probably as
long as she lives--in one of the Quemados cases 59 days after the in-
fective feeding. This unlike, indeed in contrast with, what occurs in
the infected man.

(4) She--the mosquito infective to man--feeds by day and by night--
preferably in daylight, in the early morning and the rather late after-
noon. This is true of both the newly developed Stegomyia imago and the
old ones. Those infective to man cannot be less than about 12 days old.

The statement of Marchoux: Simond and Salembini--the Commission of
the Pasteur Institute working at Rio in 1903--that the insect after be-
coming old enough to be infective to man feeds only at night is, I think,
very generally discredited. They make the categorical statement: “That
this transmission does not occur while the sun is above the horizon.”

It has been categorically disproved by the direct observations of
Seidelin and Summers-Conal--in 1915, I think--and by the more recent ones
of Gordon and Young at Manaos in 1921.

It is certainly not in accordance with epidemiological data in this
country: the West Indies or Panama.
Space.

This affects sanitary measures, making a mosquito-bar a very minor
minor
5.
protection to the individual who uses it, and rendering nugatory the
“Daylight Protection,” the dependence on which has been responsible for the
infection of so many American warships and communities.
Space.

2/ The Man Infected by the Mosquito.
(a) Naturally he must be susceptible to the disease.
(b) The period of incubation--of 44 accurately observed cases--
has been:--the shortest: 3 days, - 2hrs: and the longest: 6 days 2hrs.--
that is 3 to 6 days.
(C) Immunity to yellow fever is conferred by the attack.

Naturally, every infection which recovers must confer immunity--
temporary or permanent, local or general--else it would not recover.

Quite a number of recent writers, following the lead of the Commis-
sion of the Pasteur Institute, to which I have so often alluded--con-
sider this immunity produced by an attack as short-lived--ephemeral--
and subsequent attacks common--indeed the rule--on subsequent exposures.
I do not think so. I think the immunity conferred by an attack of yel-
low fever is a permanent one--that is, as permanent as that conferred
by small-pox or measles. This is again a negative proposition: that
men who have one attack do not have another--and is not such an easy
thing to prove. I have attempted to do so (Immunity to Yellow Fever:
Annals of Tropical Medicine & Parisitology, April 1916) (Many typograph-
ical errors in the article as printed.)
Space.
Space.
Prophylaxis of Yellow Fever.
Individual and Community.
Individual and Comparison with Malaria.

For Malaria we have as measures for individual prophy-
laxis: segregation: screening and mosquito-bars: hand-
catching and quinine.
Discuss.
Screening and Mosquito-bars.

Mosquito bars are of little use for the protection from
yellow fever of those who use them, because it is mainly
contracted in the day. Used to cover the sick man, they
are of value to others--by preventing infection of Ste-
gomyia.

Screens are worth somewhat more--if one lives close to
other houses--in that they prevent entrance of mosqui-
toes infected elsewhere. Not much, however, to one lead-
ing the ordinary city life. Don't raise your Stegomyia
inside the screens, lest accidentally you get some in-
fected man in your town.
Personal Prophylaxis.
Of so little value that it scarcely deserves mention.
Vaccination.
from the earth.

Vaccination with the killed culture of Leptospira icteroides I have
only mentioned incidentally, because I have little personal knowledge of
it and, for reasons into which I will not at present enter. I cannot satis-
factorily evaluate the data presented of its use with men. I have used it
and recommend it as a measure for individual prophylaxis to men exposed
to yellow fever. It can do no harm, there is evidence, not proof, of its
being to some extent protective & besides we wish to get as much data and
use as possible

As a general sanitary measure I recommended--indeed pressed--its
use freely, especially in the small places liable to infection.

A vaccination, if efficient and capable of general use, should be of
some sanitary value as an adjuvant even in a campaign by Control of the
Insect Host, but very much more so in small places in assisting Nature (the
fever) in lessening the number of people susceptible to yellow fever and
thus advancing the date when there are not enough to continue the life
of the causative organism.

Unfortunately, I am unable to present you any reliable data of much
value from Peru. The work was heavy: the working corps undermanned and
but little attention was paid to scientific records, or indeed to any-
thing except the struggle immediately before us. As I said, we used
vaccination, but we depended on Control of Stegomyia Breeding Places.
Vaccination?
2/ Community Prophylaxis may be:

(A) Elimination of yellow fever from a community in which it
exists,

(B) Prevention of introduction of yellow fever into a community
free from it.

(A) Elimination of yellow fever from a community in which it exists.
For yellow fever to continue in a community it is in general necessary
that there exist in it at the same time men with yellow fever: active Ste-
gomyiae: men susceptible to yellow fever: the insects having access to
both classes of men.
Space.

A break in this chain for a short time will eliminate yellow fever.
Complete control over any one of the three factors will suffice to do so.
It is to break the first two links that sanitarians have worked. We will
see later the importance of the last one in Nature's method of elimination.

Sanitarians' Methods. Of the first two it seems, indeed, is more natural
to attempt the control of the human host. I say is in all confidence, be-
cause this was the method relied on in all the earlier attempts of yellow
fever eradication--the first of which was the brilliant work of Gorgas at
Havana. Gorgas at Havana and at Panama: Cruz at Rio: and Liceaga at Vera
Cruz all made this the principal point of attack. All, however, also used
control of Stegomyia breeding as an adjuvant thereto.

Method by Control of the Human Host. By this method all cases of yel-
low fever are to be isolated, as soon as they occur, from mosquitoes--pre-
ferably in screened cages in screened wards--until no longer infective to
them and such mosquitoes as have had access to them before isolation, de-
stroyed by fumigation. The detail is too well known to describe.

Difficulties of this Method. For this method it is a prerequisite
that the cases of yellow fever be found as they occur, and this is the dif-
dif-
8.
ficulty. In a place in which yellow fever is permanently endemic only a
small proportion of the cases are recognized--practically none in child-
ren, among whom it mainly occurs--and we can rarely, in such a community,
find so nearly all of the cases of yellow fever as to enable us to con-
trol the human host sufficiently to eliminate it. The disease can be
very much lessened by this method, but elimination would scarcely ever re-
sult. This was shown in Panama. We begun by relying on this method--
and failed.
Space.

The success at Havana: Vera Cruz: Rio and elsewhere we believe was
mainly due to the campaign which was waged simultaneously, as an adjuvant
to the above, against Stegomyia--i. e. to incidental control of the in-
sect host. At Panama it certainly was.
Space.

In such endemic centres then, I would rely solely on the control of
Stegomyia production. I would not even attempt to combine the methods.
In 1908 I wrote: “Were the probliem to rid of yellow fever a town in the
Tropics in which it is endemic--say Guayaquil--I would concentrate all my
work on this mosquito: I would not isolate a man sick of yellow fever: I
would not fumigate a room (save possibly as a measure of protection to
those in its immediate neighborhood). As a measure of general sanitation--
helping to rid the town of yellow fever, their value would not pay for the
trouble they caused, if, indeed, they had any value at all for this purpose.”
Connor followed this method for Guayaquil and you all know the result.
Space.

The first campaign against yellow fever based solely on Control of Ste-
gomyia, was that of Converse at Iquitos in 1913: then Beverly at Buenaven-
tura in 1916: Connor in Guayaquil--the first work on a large scale--and our
Peruvian work in 1920 and 1921 and that in Mexico and Central America dur-
ing the same years. The principle of this method was pressed on the Brazil-
Brazil-

9.
ians in 1916 by myself and again by Lyster in 1920, but I do not know
how they handled the out-break in Pernambuco (1919)

It is fair to say then, that this method: Control of the Insect
Host--by itself, uncomplicated, not combined with isolation of the sick
or with fumigation--is, for an endemic focus of yellow fever--not only
the method of election, but the only one a modern sanitarian would con-
sider and that is why I have not gone into the detail methods of Control
of the Human Host.
Space. of Control of the Human

The same is in general--although not so exclusively--true for a gen-
eralized epidemic in the tropics.

With a newly introduced infection the above may not apply--indeed
usually will not.
Space.
Prophylaxis of Yellow Fever by Control of the Insect Host.

To utilize this method of prophylaxis we need consider but three
points in the Entomology of our insect host.

1/ It is, in Panama, 9 or 12 days from the egg to the imago, more
in cooler weater. In Piura in August it was 22 days minimally cool weather.

2/ It is a small insect and a # 18 mesh wire screen is required to
prevent its passage.

3 3/ It breeds in artificial (man-made) containers--a “pot-breeder,”
Theobald calls it--and hence in close proximity to man, in and about
whose dwellings it spends its life--the arche type of a domestic mosquito.

For its breeding place the preference is for small collections of
clear water in a shady and rather dark place. It is, however, quite a-
daptable and readily takes the next best when the best is not available:
When there is nothing better, she takes to muddy water: to house gutters:
knot-holes in trees: small hollows in rocks: the axils of certain plants--
as colocasias and young bananas--and developes no little ingenuity in pro-
pro-
10.
viding for the continuation of the species.
Space.

There is a limit to its adaptability--we have not found it breeding--
from egg to pupa--in any collection of water with only earth sides.
(Francis: Catacaos: Casa Grande)
Complete breeding places: gutters in New Orleans.

She does not breed in marshes: streams: ponds or woods: hence it is
not necessary to drain marshes: train streams: cut down jungle etc.
(Sir Patrick Manson)

With this knowledge of its breeding habits: of its size: of the length
of its life-cycle we can control its production and we can do it easily.
As with Anopheles, the attack is made on its breeding places. But we have
no draining of marshes: training of streams etc. These breeding places
are all near residences and practically all in artificial containers: water
jars: old tin cans: the bowl in which the table leg stands etc. In the
house and in the court they are various and numerous in the tropics.
Space.

We have then, only to get rid of water in artificial containers or pre-
vent access to it by the mosquito. For this we (1) remove the receptacle:
(2) put live fish in it; (3) empty it completely at least once a week: (4)
cover or screen it or (5) oil the water--also once a week.
Any one of these methods properly carried out is efficient.

(1) is the best always, where possible, and when impossible in its en-
tirety, as is usually the case, remove as many of them as possible, so as
to lessen the number we have to care for.
Piura: Trujillo etc.
The others according to circumstances.
Large containers--as New Orleans cisterns: Guayaquil tanks.

Time element in epidemic--not so importantiin endemic focus.
endemic focus.
11.

When the preferential breeding places are destroyed and the insect
takes to the out-of-the-way ones, a pan of water placed in a shady corner
of the court will attract her back from her knot-holes and leaf axils.
This is emptied at the weekly inspection and filled again. Howlett has
called this a “trap breeding place.”

When water is emptied, Stegomyia larvae dive for the bottomand,
unless it be completely emptied, the last drops will be loaded with them.
It is best to scour the insice of the container with a broom or cloth or
allow it to dry, as they can live in very little water.
Paita--straining water.
General Method of examination of water.
Method by pouring.

Fish: History: Need not examine for larvae--only see if fish are
alive.
Critical Number of Stegomyia for Propagation of Yellow Fever:

It is not necessary to eliminate the mosquito to eliminate yellow
fever. If the insects are brought below a certain number the disease will
die out. This is common sense, as well as observation.

Obviously, this critical number with which the disease just holds
its own will vary for any place directly as the proportion of men immune
to yellow fever to the total population. Thus: if with 100 cases of yel-
low fever introduced into a community in which all were susceptible to yel-
low fever, the number of Stegomyia were such that exactly 100 men would be
infected from them, the disease would neither die out nor increase. This
would be the critical number of Stegomyia for this place and time. With
less than this, less than 100 men would be infected and the fever would
die out. If more, it would increase. Now if 1/4 of the inhabitants are
immune to yellow fever, obviously the same number of mosquitoes which in-
fected 100 men before would now infect only 75--1/4 of their bites going
to immunes, and hence wasted--and the disease would die out. The critical

critical
12.
number now would be 1/3 greater than formerly.

Obviously then this critical number, below which the Stegomyia must
be brought to eliminate fever is less in a town as the proportion of sus-
ceptible people increase and more intensive work is required to eliminate
it from such a community, other things being equal, than from one in
which a large proportion of the population is immune. Such was White's
work in /05 in New Orleans.
Pareja: No. of susceptible people lessened by vaccination.

I have said that the presence of “men susceptible to yellow fever”
was necessary for the continuance of yellow fever in a community and
spoken of the importance of this link in Nature's method of eliminating
the disease.

Yellow fever has disappeared from a great number of towns in the
American and African Tropics in which no sanitary work has been done and
in which Stegomyia is abundant. I could give a score of instances.
(Give instances.)

I would explain this disappearance as due to the lack of susceptible
people sufficient to continue the life of the parasite--to the “failure
of the human host.”

As an attack of yellow fever produces an immunity--certainly a tem-
porary one--the continuance of the disease lessens the number of suscep-
tible people in the community and unless others are supplied, would in
time leave no people susceptible to it and must itself disappear. Even before that would occur it is easy to see that yellow fever would disappear On account of
the small number left not being sufficiently available to infected Ste-
gomyia to continue the life of the causative organism. The infection,
then, having no resevoir host, dies out when its human host is sufficiently
exhausted.

This would be less apt to occur in large towns or those receiving
an influx of susceptible people. In them the immigrants and the larger
larger
13
number of babies furnish the susceptible material necessary for the con-
tinuance of the parasite. And, indeed, it is only in such towns that
this has not occurred.

Should the susceptible human material, immigrants and babies, be at
any time insufficient to continue the life of the parasite it would die
and the fever disappear, permanently unless reintroduced. Naturally, a
town thus freed of yellow fever will in time raise up a generation sus-
ceptible to it and if the disease be reintroduced. Stegomyia being still
present, there will be an epidemic, affecting those born since the immu-
nization of the town, and hence to an extent proportional to the interval
of freedom. This is a matter of common observation. I think.
Paita: Buena Ventura.

Spontaneous elimination of yellow fever is not rare and, unless re-
introduced, outbreaks do not recur in towns in which this occurred, even
on influx of strangers. When reintroduced epidemics appear among the in-
digenes, especially the youth, as well as strangers. These are reinfect-
ions, not recrudescences.

It is worth contrasting these two methods for the elimination of
yellow fever. That by the control of the insect host is undoubtedly the
method of election for the sanitarian, while the method by which it is
eliminated in nature from endemic foci is by failure of the human host.
Less eligible, doubtless, but efficient and of uncalculable value to us
in our attempt to eliminate yellow fever from the earth.

Contrast with malaria: Malaria confers minimal immunity and men are
carriers: resevoir hosts. The fact that this spontaneous elimination of
yellow fever is so common is evidence that no animal generally and close-
ly associated with man in the tropics is a resevoir host to the causative
organism of yellow fever.

Vaccination with the killed culture of Leptospira icteroides I have
only mentioned incidentally, because I have little personal knowledge of
it and, for reasons into which I will not at present enter, I cannot satis-
satis-
14.
factorily evaluate the data presented of its use with men. I have used it
and recommended it as a measure for individual prophylaxis to men exposed
to yellow fever. It can do no harm, and there is evidence of its protect-
ive effect, and, besides, we wish to get as much data on it as possible.
(As a general sanitary measure I recommended--indeed pressed--its use
freely, especially in the small places liable to infection).

A vaccination, if efficient and capable of general use, should be of
some sanitary value, as an adjuvant, even in a campaign by Control of the
Insect Host, but very much more so in small places in assisting Nature
(the fever) in lessening the number of people susceptible to yellow fever
and thus advancing the date when there are not enough to continue the
life of the causative organism.
Space.

Unfortunately, I am unable to present you any reliable data of much
value from Peru. The work was heavy: the working corps undermanned and
but little attention was paid to scientific records, or, indeed, to any-
thing except the struggle immediately before us. As I said, we used vac-
cination, but we depended on control of stegomyia breeding places.
breeding places.

B/ Prevention of introduction of yellow fever into a community free
from it. This may be by (1) what are called--with little regard for
etymology--“measures of Quarantine,” or (2) rendering the place to be
protected incapable of propagating yellow fever--“non-infectable.”

The 1st. is by preventing the entrance of infected men, sick or in
the stage of incubation, and of infected mosquitoes. Both harbor the
parasite and from both it may be transmitted to people in the community.
The methods of doing this are too well known to describe.
Maritime Quarantine.
Cordon Sanitaire.

The 2nd. method is to free the community to be protected from Stegomyia.
If this be done, men, although infected, may be ignored (Peru) and infect-
ed mosquitoes (if arriving on a vessel) may be killed--or even if intro-
duced, since they could not breed in the community, would at most produce
a few primary cases of yellow fever--of little sanitary importance.
This is evidently the method of election.
Honolulu: Peru: Mexico etc.

There are two postulates in the sanitation of yellow fever developed
since the mechanism of its conveyance became known, which I especially
wish to press on your attention:

1/ In the elimination of yellow fever from endemic centers the
Method by Control of Stegomyia Breeding Places is the method of election
to the exclusion of all others.

2/ That elimination of Stegomyiae is not necessary for the elimi-
nation of yellow fever. A sufficient reduction in the number of Stego-
myia will completely eliminate yellow fever.
And here is one equally important in its epidemiology:

3/ That in any community a sufficient supply of people susceptible
to yellow fever, either by immigration or by birth, is necessary to con-
tinue infection in that community--failing which it will die out.

This is Nature's method for the elimination of yellow fever and is
common in small and moderate sized towns, receiving little immigration of
susceptible people. This we have called “Elimination of Yellow Fever by
Failure of the Human Host.”

Once eliminated in any way yellow fever will not reappear unless re-
introduced:--the parasite reintroduced in one of its hosts.
Space.

“Mechanism of the Spontaneous Elimination of Yellow Fever from
Endemic Centers.” (Annals of Tropical Medicine & Parisitology, Liverpool
(Journal, March 15, 1920: Vol Xlll, No. 4.
